awd_titl_txt: Stereolithography: Enabling Polymer Network and Multi-Scale Structure Control
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports fundamental research that integrates material chemistry and mechanics to define a technology which can lead to advanced manufacturing of 3D printed thermosets with enhanced mechanical properties. Thermoset structures containing stiff and soft domains that mimic the hierarchical structure of bone, nacre, bamboo and pearlite steels will be developed by using stereolithography 3D printing in conjunction with phase separation. The experimental work will be guided by modeling to optimize the network structure and the multiscale architecture of the material, in order to achieve strength and toughness of the additive manufactured (AM) parts superior to those of the structurally homogeneous thermosets used today. Polymer nanocomposite AM parts are increasingly important for applications in dental, biomedical, wearable electronics, aerospace, and automotive industries. Therefore, results from this research will benefit the U.S. economy and society. This project integrates research with an education plan, which encompasses course development, education of graduate students, integration of undergraduate students in research, outreach to K-12 and the promotion of STEM.  

The objective of this research is to innovate the photopolymerization 3D printing technique called stereolithography (SLA) to allow for the production of thermosets with network structure and architecture modulated on multiple scales. The project aims to develop material design rules for heterogeneous thermosets and to establish new SLA methods by combining photo-crosslinking with phase separation. This activity will (i) develop SLA as an additive manufacturing method for thermosets with structure controlled on multiple length scales, including on scales finer than the printing resolution, and (ii) develop the concept and the methods to design the multiscale structure so as to enhance its toughness without compromising the strength and stiffness of the thermoset. This will be achieved by integrating modeling and experimentation. The developed technologies will be applicable to other polymeric systems to control these and other sets of properties, such as the thermal and electrical conductivities.  This research will also provide education in advanced manufacturing, materials modeling and polymer research to graduate and undergraduate students, while dissemination and outreach to K-12 will increase the impact of the project activities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
Polymeric networks known as thermosets have a broad range of applications, from thin films in microelectronics to macroscopic parts used in the automotive industry. The polymeric chains in these materials are densely crosslinked. The high crosslinking density imparts high stiffness and strength, but limits ductility and toughness. Epoxies and acrylics are important thermosets which are crosslinked (cured) by exposure to elevated temperature and to UV light, respectively. Improving the toughness of these materials, particularly when they are produced by 3D printing, is a long-standing goal.

In this project we addressed this problem by using phase separation in the context of photocurable acrylics. As the acrylic network develops during exposure to UV irradiation by the polymerization of monomeric acrylates, long chain additive molecules tend to phase separate from the growing network. This produces additive-rich subdomains. By the appropriate selection of the additives, the control of the state of the material within subdomains and the control of the subdomain size and number density, it is possible to improve the toughness of the material without sacrificing its strength and stiffness. This goal was achieved in the present program by combining the following: (i) adequate chemistry of the network, including a combination of stiff backbone diacrylates and high cohesion energy chain extenders, (ii) the use of phase separating additives based on PMMA functionalized with epoxide and hydroxyl groups, (iii) the use of a two-phase curing procedure in which UV curing/network growth and phase separation take place first, followed by thermal curing of the phase separated moieties within the subdomains, (iv) the use of appropriate processing parameters to enable the formation of small elastomeric subdomains. The resulting elastomeric subdomains enhance the toughness, while the base network provides stiffness, strength and creep resistance. This material can be 3D printed and the multiscale structure responsible for these properties develops by itself during printing and curing. Modeling was used at all steps of this investigation to develop a deeper understanding of the structure-properties relationship and to guide network design. The net outcome of this activity is the chemical composition and processing method required to produce this advanced thermoset material.

The broader impact of the research is related to the potential use of this type of material in a broad range of applications. Many materials we use every day, as well as many biological materials, are of fibrous type, i.e. are made from filaments connected into a network. The computational results of this work facilitate the design of networks and enable designing new classes of micro and nanofiber network-based products. This project has trained a diverse group of undergraduate and graduate students, including female students which are under-represented in engineering, who worked collaboratively on materials chemistry and synthesis, experimental testing, and computational modeling. Outreach to local high schools was performed during all summers of the program.


Last Modified: 09/15/2024
Modified by: Catalin R Picu
